Award.AwardTitle: 2010 Project: Arabidopsis 2010: Transcriptomes for Functional and Evolutionary Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
A basic challenge in the life sciences is to understand how genetic variation among individuals (DNA sequence differences) leads to variation in traits, for example, eye color in animals or crop yield in plants. Ultimately, trait differences among individuals result from differences in the kind or amount of molecules (for example, RNA and protein molecules) produced by cells. In this project, the investigators will generate a resource to address the fundamental question of how differences in DNA sequences among individuals lead to the production of different RNA molecules, which in turn affect protein types, levels, and whole-organism traits. To do this, the investigators will exploit newly developed technologies, including so-called 'second generation' DNA sequencing methods, to characterize in a highly cost effective manner the majority of RNA molecules from 19 diverse strains of the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, for which sequenced genomes are available.
A general outcome will be an understanding of how genetic variation affects RNA levels, and hence how DNA differences lead to trait differences. Specifically, the resource will allow investigators from around the United States and the world to understand the regulation of genes relevant to a multitude of traits of critical importance for agriculture in the coming century. The resource of sequence data that will be generated by the project will be released publically via the deposition in the DNA sequence database of the USA National Center for Biotechnology. Internet links to these data, and a description of the project, will be available on website of the lead project investigator within the public University of Utah website. Hands-on training will be provided to each of the undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers involved in the project. The project will expose trainees to advanced biological technologies and analysis methods of ever increasing importance in biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nearly all populations of organisms harbor genetic variation – differences in DNA sequence among individuals – that can affect phenotypes (for example, height in humans or yield in crop plants). A central challenge in the genomics era is to identify the genetic differences that distinguish individuals, and to understand how these differences in DNA sequences lead to differences in phenotypes. Increasingly, a focus of this endeavor has been to elucidate how genetic variants affect the expression of genes that encode the products (for instance, proteins) that allow cells to function. The central aims of this NSF-sponsored project were to characterize the complement of expressed gene sequences in 19 strains of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana (hereafter Arabidopsis), and to understand how genetic differences between strains result in differences in the expression of genes that lead to differences in organismal phenotypes. Arabidopsis is an attractive organism in which to perform these studies as a wealth of genetic tools and strain collections are available. Specifically, the study used the parental strains of the Multiparent Advanced Generation InterCross (MAGIC) lines for which genome sequences were available. From each of the 19 Arabidopsis parents of the MAGIC lines, the complement of transcribed sequences was detected using an advanced method called RNA-seq (briefly, the method allows the determination of transcribed sequences by massively parallel DNA sequencing).

From the resulting RNA-seq reads produced with NSF funds, we found that aspects of gene expression in Arabidopsis differed in several ways among strains. First, expression for some genes varied in an effectively qualitative manner (that is, in one strain the gene is expressed, and in another it is not expressed). By examining the underlying sequences of the respective genes in each strain, we found that large differences in gene sequences were often responsible for these major differences in gene expression. In many cases, the presence or absence of all or part of a gene could explain the observed expression variation. By using the RNA-seq data, we were able to annotate each genome to reflect such differences in gene structure among strains. Second, in other cases differences in gene expression were more quantitative, with the complement of RNA abundance differing among strains by up to several fold or more (we detected this type of variation for nearly half of genes for which we could detect expression with the RNA-seq data). By employing several approaches, we established that much of this expression variation is due to sequence variation nearby genes that must affect either the transcription level of genes or subsequent RNA stability. Finally, this study found that differences in the splicing of genes, as well as in the alternative use of gene endings (so-called polyA sites), contributes to the complexity of divergent gene expression in the Arabidopsis population. In general, the most variation in gene expression was observed for those genes annotated as responding to the environment (especially the biotic environment, such as pathogens or herbivores that are plant pests).

The resources, findings and outreach efforts funded by this project are of high relevance to the community in several ways. First, our description of the genes that are present in each of the MAGIC founder strains is a major resource for many investigators who are using the MAGIC lines. The MAGIC genetic cross resource allows genes for phenotypes such as drought or pathogen resistance to be localized to very small genomic regions.
